definition: to scare/to intimidate/to threaten/(interjection showing disapproval) tut-tut/(interjection showing astonishment)

sentences.english: You are afraid of ghosts and things are not like to scare themselves out of it?
sentences.chinese: 鬼和你怕的东西不都是想出来吓唬自己的吗？

sentences.english: And the imperialist always also likes to come formidably with his of gally person.
sentences.chinese: 而帝国主义者也总是喜欢以自己的强大来吓唬人的。

sentences.english: Someone like you won't spook me.
sentences.chinese: 像你这样的人吓唬不了我。

sentences.english: Of oaths and gibberish frightening girls and boys.
sentences.chinese: 用洋话骂人吓唬男孩和女娃。

sentences.english: Bat loves scaring the others, so they decide to give him a taste of his own medicine.
sentences.chinese: 蝙蝠喜欢吓唬别人，所以大家想让他自食恶果一下。

sentences.english: I don't intimidate the public, I only intimidate those corrupt officials.
sentences.chinese: 我从来不吓唬老百姓，只吓唬那些贪官污吏。

sentences.english: I don't intimidate the public, I only intimidate those corrupt officials.
sentences.chinese: 我从来不吓唬老百姓，只吓唬那些贪官污吏。

sentences.english: They only want to scare society.
We don't want to alarm people but we want them to be prepared.
sentences.chinese: 我们并不想吓唬人，但是我们希望人们做好准备。

sentences.english: Don't frighten him. He's telling the truth.
sentences.chinese: 不要吓唬他，他在讲实话。

sentences.english: and you have people running around scaring you.
sentences.chinese: 然后人们围着你跑，吓唬你。

sentences.english: This idiom means relying on another 's power to bully or frighten others.
sentences.chinese: 这个成语用来比喻依仗别人的势力去欺压人或吓唬人。

sentences.english: The rascal hectored the boy into taking out all of his money.
sentences.chinese: 吓唬小男孩，让他掏出了所有的钱。

sentences.english: She threatened the children with a walloping.
sentences.chinese: 她吓唬孩子说要狠狠打他们一顿。

sentences.english: The teacher cowed the pupils with his hard eyes.
sentences.chinese: 老师用严厉的目光吓唬学生们。

definition: to play tricks on/to make fun of/to tease
to disturb/to look for trouble/to stir up a row/to bother sb intentionally
lit. dress up as God, play the devil (idiom); fig. to mystify/to deceive people/to scam
to scare/to intimidate/to threaten/(interjection showing disapproval) tut-tut/(interjection showing astonishment)
lit. show strength while weak inside (idiom); appearing fierce while cowardly at heart/a sheep in wolf's clothing
to cheat/to swindle/to deceive/to get on (a horse etc) by swinging one leg over
to be scared out of one's wits/to scare stiff
to spur sb into action by making negative remarks
